Potential Failure Mode: Mura appearing on display when touch panel is activated.
Potential Failure Effects: Appearance of localized distortion on display
Potential Causes: Pressure induced to the back of Display when Touch Panel is activated due to lack of clearance between the Display and underlying components causing interference.
Preventive Controls:
Provide sufficient clearance between the back of display and underlying components.    Less rigid display
components will need higher clearance to accommodate tendency to bend when Touch Panel is activated.
Detection Controls: Include display mura symptom in the list of check items during Engineering and Qualification testing.

Potential Failure Mode: Display showing random lines on screen
Potential Causes: Lack of supporting features on display integration allowing for movement during impact resulting to damage on Display FPC.
Preventive Controls: Provide fillers e.g. foam pad to fill up void area between FPC bend area and edge of Display to restrict movement during impact.
Detection Controls: Teardown inspection on test samples following Drop tests

Potential Causes: Peeling off of LED light bar from Back Light Unit (BLU) frame allowing for light to leak out.
Preventive Controls: Select adhesive material that can effectively perform at extreme temp.
Detection Controls:
High temperature Burn-in
Drop Test
Tumble Test

Potential Causes: Excessive pressure being applied to the backlight in display integration stack-up design.
Preventive Controls:
Minimize compression to the backlight in the display integration
 - LCD rubber boot
 - EMI spring position and force
Detection Controls:
Tolerance Analysis on display stackup to check for possible interference and verify equal compression around entire perimeter.

Manufacturing test under various display color backgrounds.

Potential Failure Effects: Appearance of localized distortion on display
Potential Causes: Deformation of the backlight diffuser film due to lack of sufficient anchor points resulting to the locating anchors to deform during mechanical tests
Preventive Controls: Design for sufficient anchor points to support the backlight diffuser film from folding during mechanical tests.

Potential Causes: Crack on FPC display due to abrupt change in thickness causing sharp bend radius and high strain on FPC conductors.
Preventive Controls:
Design guidelines on FPC around bend areas
1) FPC's identified as dynamic shall specify conductor material as 1mil Rolled Annealed Copper (RA-Cu).
2) Transitions in trace direction shall be placed outside of bend areas and away from areas where the width of the FPC changes.
3) FPC thickness transitions shall not occur within the bend region and shall not be in the same location as the FPC width transition.
4)  Hard stiffener e.g. stainless shall not occur parallel to the same location as the FPC trace.
5) There should be no via holes (PTH) present within the bend region of the FPC.

Potential Causes:
Lack of support structure on the back of display.
Double-sided adhesive on backlight frame is not wide enough and adhesive strength is not adequate.
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide support structure on the corners of the display to minimize movement of the backlight module during drops or tumble.
Backlight adhesive contact area and adhesive strength should be sufficient to allow the backlight module to withstand impact shock.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Drop test across temperature
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Ripples on display when finger pressed
Potential Failure Effects: Appearance of localized distortion on display
Potential Causes: Interference points to the back of display module when pressure is applied on the display.
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide a uniform support structure on the back of display. 
Components placed underneath the display should have sufficient clearance to prevent interference when pressure is applied on the display during normal use.
Detection Controls: Add check item for ripples on display when pressure is applied during function testing.

Potential Causes: TP glass shattering due to cracks initiating from the edges due to chippings i.e., poor edge quality.
Preventive Controls:
Use alumino-silicate (Corning Gorilla Glass or equivalent) for applications with chemical strengthening.  Alumino-silicate glass can be post processed with Hydroflouric acid etch to improve edge quality.
Specifications for glass component should include the glass substrate material.
Detection Controls:
Four-point bend testing on glass components
First Article Inspection with microscope check on the glass edges for presence of chipping.
Thermal Shock
Drop Test across temperature
Tumble Test
Ball Drop on Touch Panel/ Display

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel damaged on the edge area
Potential Causes: Housing design did not adequately protect the edges of the touch panel
Preventive Controls:
Design should provide bottom edge protection to housing and keypad bezel and maintain the active area aligned within the  touch panel specification.
Touch panel design should include venting feature. Vent will allow for pressure equalization between touch panel and atmosphere.
Detection Controls:
Perform touch panel edge wear/ swipe testing.
Touch Panel durability life test.

Potential Failure Mode: IP leak failure on Touch Panel
Potential Failure Effects: IP seal compromised and could result to potential function loss
Potential Causes: Touch panel sensor surface does not cover the touch panel outline so it does not match with sealing adhesive area.
Preventive Controls: Touch panel design should ensure the outline is covered. Add fake sensor material if required to cover any exposed areas and use resin to fill any gaps.

Potential Failure Effects: Touch Panel partially operative or permanently damage
Potential Causes: Thickness of metal jumper between 8 - 16 microns could get damaged and bridge the glass-glass SITO touch panel configuration.
Preventive Controls: Design should ensure minimum thickness of 24 microns on glass-glass SITO (single-sided ITO) touch panel configuration.
Detection Controls: Thermal Shock + Operating Temperature Cycling + Vibration + ESD

Potential Failure Effects: Puffiness increases the stress on the ITO layer and can lead to premature breakdown of the ITO resulting in non-linearity and dead zones.
Potential Causes:
Puffiness caused by the blocking of the vents in the touch panel design.
Vents can be blocked due to the flow of the adhesive that bonds the layers of the touch panel into the venting areas.
Preventive Controls:
Design to ensure the vents will not be blocked as a result of adhesive flow. 
The Display/Touch Panel gasket should be designed to provide relief in the areas of the vent to allow for unrestricted air flow.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Operating Temperature Cycling
Low Temperature Operating Function Test
High Temperature Operating Function Test

Potential Failure Mode: Distorted image when pressure is applied to Touch Panel
Potential Causes: Inadequate clearance between Touch Panel / Display shield can and mainboard shields causing pressure being applied on back of display resulting to localized distortion.
Preventive Controls:
1) Perform 1st order approximation (hand calculation) of Touch Panel / Display bending during user activation, approximately 100 grams.
2) Perform tolerance analysis to determine clearance between display shield and mainboard shield on the worst case stack-up. Clearance should be greater than the first order approximation.
3) Perform FEA of finalized Touch Panel + Display design to determine maximum applied force to cause interference between display shield can and mainboard shields.  There should be clearance with the shield can even in loaded condition.
Detection Controls:
Perform following test to establish presence or conditions necessary to create LCD distortion from Touch Panel use.  

First determine the location minimum clearance between the shield can of the Display and mainboard.  Apply compression at this location.
a) Test on Instron machine. Lay sample on a hard flat surface.
b) Have the plunger push down on the Touch Panel to a given force carefully observing the Display during the pull away for pressure marks.
c) If no pressure marks observed, increase pressure by 10g increments until distortion is observed.

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel is lifting up from plastic housing
Potential Failure Effects: Sealing compromised around Touch Panel could result to function loss.
Potential Causes:
Incorrect contact angle between the Touch Panel, Double-sided adhesive and Plastic housing.
Impurities on the bonding surface between Touch Panel and Plastic housing and bonding fixture parameters not optimized.
Preventive Controls:
Design should establish if the contact angle between mating surfaces is correct.  Dyne Pen test can be used for this purpose. Confirm there is no interference between the mating surfaces e.g. TP sensor film, FPC, etc.
Ensure cleanliness on the bonding surfaces.  Consider plasma cleaning if needed.
Ensure bonding parameters i.e., pressure and hold time are optimized.
Detection Controls:
Thermal Shock
Drop Test across temperature
Tumble Test

Potential Failure Mode: Touch Panel cracking during AFM test cycle
Potential Failure Effects: Possible premature Touch Panel failure in the field rendering the device inoperable
Potential Causes:
Lack of protective bezel or ledge on top housing to protect the Touch Panel / Display assembly.
Prioritization of ID preference over mechanical design intent.
Preventive Controls: Design should include protective features such as bezel depth on Top Housing to protect the Touch Panel / Display assembly.
Detection Controls:
mini-AFM test cycle
AFM test cycle
Drops across temperature
Tumble test

Potential Failure Mode: Scratches and damages on Touch Panel of Tablet products.
Potential Causes: The  anti-reflective coating application process of using Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) is susceptible to damage compared to the Sputtering process regardless of the hardness of the coating.
Preventive Controls:
1) Sputtering deposition process should be the preferred process for anti-reflective coating.

2) Tablet SKU's should always be released with a screen protector accessory to prevent premature wear out on touch panel of the tablet.
Detection Controls: Conduct Falling Sand testmethod following ASTM D968-22 method A.
